description:
Tragedy Looper is a scenario-based deduction game for two to four players: one mastermind and one to three protagonists. The game consists of four location boards and a number of character cards. Each scenario features a number of characters, hidden roles for these characters (serial killer, conspiracy theorist, friend), and some pre-set tragedies (murder, suicide).

Each "day" (turn), players and the mastermind play three face-down cards onto the characters, then reveal them to move the characters around or affect their paranoia or goodwill stats. At the end of each day (turn), if the scenario has a tragedy set for that day, it happens if the conditions are met, i.e., certain characters have certain stats or are in a certain location together (or not together) with others. As tragedies happen, players loop back in time, restarting the scenario from the beginning and trying to deduce who the culprit was and why the tragedy occurred.

The players win if they manage to maintain status quo — that is, if no tragedies occur to the key individuals — for a set number of days, within a set number of loops. If not, the mastermind wins.

Tragedy Looper was originally released in Japan as æƒ¨åŠ‡RoopeR in 2011; the first english version of the game was released in 2014.

Patrol Angis is a 15 mm skirmish level miniature game set in The Ion Age universe. The Prydian, Marcher Barons and Khanate Empire have been revealed as factions in this future/scifi setting.

Patrol Angis focuses on one platoon of miniatures per force with a player controlling one or more forces in play. The game uses the often-overlooked D8, the eight-sided die.

Some minis in the line are available, and the rules are in playtest. A 28 mm miniature range is also in development.

"A Simple Game of Ancient Warfare between the Greek City State Alliance and Persian Empire From 499-479 BC."

From the rulebook:

IMPACT and MELEE: Persian Wars - 499-479 BC
A simple and quick war game of a GREEK vs. PERSIAN battle

Game pieces are represented by top down full color photos of Greek and Persian warriors of the time of PERSIAN WARS (@ 499-479 BC).    Print out the game board (6 x 4 rectangle of squares sized on an 8.5”x 11” piece of paper). You will need to provide your own six-sided dice.


Players set up on opposite sides of the map, and maneuver their units on the squares to attack their opponent's units.  Victory occurs when one side has eliminated the enemy units that were designated in the "How to Win" victory conditions.

From the game's website:

"You play the role of the insurgent leader rebelling against the Japanese Occupiers. The player with the most number of Valour points by the time the Commanding General is defeated wins the game."

Battlebox is a deckbuilding game. Players start the game with a Tactical Deck of 10 cards, made up of 7 basic resource cards and 3 Solo Vigilante mission cards, and 80 Life Points.

During every turn, players draw 5 cards from their own Tactical Deck and use the 5 cards to acquire more powerful cards (Resources, Plans or Mission). Players may also play Plan or Mission cards if they are part of the 5 drawn cards. Plan cards help players complete Missions.

Playing a Mission card leads to a draw from the Warzone deck. If the player fulfills the requirements of the drawn Warzone card, he completes the mission and gains the Valour points and benefits listed on the card. A failed mission leads to loss of Life Points listed on the same card. Reaching 0 Life Points leads to the skipping of the next turn, and reduction of maximum Life Points by 20. When the maximum Life Points reaches 0, the player is out of the game.

The player with the highest number of Valour points at the end of the game wins.

Board game where players in three rounds answer trivia questions about Croatian history, culture, sport, music, geography, etc.

Društvena igra na ploÄi u kojoj igraÄi u tri kruga odgovaraju na pitanja vezana za hrvatsku povijest, kulturu, sport, glazbu, zemljopis…

Solitaire statistical replay game on Soccer, where each team is rated for a lot of statistics (shots on goal, fouls for, fouls against, possession percentage, counterattack, defense, etc.) and the player has to fill a game sheet before each game - as each match differs according to the comparison of the opposing teams.

When he/she has fill up the game sheet, he alternate rolling a percentage dice on the Game Flow chart to see what happens in the match. Result may vary from Missing opportunity, shot on goal, change of possession, penalty, goal and many other possibilities.
Each match lasts about half an hour after you have taken confidence with the system.

At the moment the following sets are available (each a complete game by itself): Champions League 2011/12, Champions League 2012/13, Italian Serie A 2012/13, English Premier League 2012/13, Spanish Liga 2012/13, German Bundesliga 2012/13

Join in the valiant battle to end the ultimate stalemate of good vs. evil and etch the final outcome into history. Regnum Angelica is a two-player strategic card/board game pitting Gabriel and his army of archangels against Beelzebub and the dark forces of the fallen. Wield the three elements of fire, earth and water in angelic combat, use ancient angelic scripts to gain an advantage over your opponent, or deploy pillars to protect your troops in an attempt to infiltrate the enemy's realm.

Regnum Angelica is played with one player having the white deck to represent the archangels of Gabriel, and the other the black deck to represent Beelzebub and his army of fallen angels. Each deck consists of three types of cards: Angels, which are your main combat units; Angelic Scripts, written in the ancient celestial alphabet (Malachim) and granting the angels special abilities to assist them in infiltrating the enemy realm; and Pillars, which call up the elements of earth, fire, or water to protect them from enemy attacks.

Each army has a power meter which is charged when either side's angels visit earth. The power meter must be carefully managed if you hope to crush your opponent as your power meter determines your movement and your ability to execute the Malachim. If too many Angelic scripts are played, then your mobility on the board suffers; if, on the other hand, you use your power for movement, then your ability to harness the powers of the angelic scripts wanes.

Mobility or Angelic Scripts? Have your angels protect your realm, or go on the full offensive to penetrate your enemies kingdom? Execute your scripts now, burn them for precious power, or save them to use with other scripts to pull off powerful combinations? Many of these tactical decisions await you as you control the most powerful beings in the universe of Regnum Angelica!

In Cosmos, players take turns exploring the universe, building far-flung colonies, and collecting taxes (for once, we're on the right side of taxes!).  The goal of the game is to make the most money from the economic opportunities of exploring space, while elbowing out the market competition.  Central market mechanics allow players to compete by increasing or decreasing universal resource prices, while limited resources make each region of space a hotly-contested competition for colonies.  The game ends when the universe is totally explored--meaning if you're sitting in dead last without a hope, you can explore your heart out and rush the game to an untimely conclusion.

Cosmos is very straightforward to learn, and a typical game takes around 30-45 minutes. Cosmos is simple enough for casual gamers to play (and win), but complex enough to keep the interest of more competitive or experienced gamers. Turns are quick, and the game mechanics are easy to remember.

Most conflict in Cosmos is indirect, making this a great game for two players--even those who may be mismatched in competitive nature or gaming experience (read: the hobbyist and the spouse). At the same time, Cosmos allows up to eight players, making it a decent party game, although it gets a bit crowded and far more competitive at six.

Overall, this is a highly replayable, very entertaining game with a really broad appeal and low commitment requirements.

Bicycle Race is a fast-playing 18-card microgame of bluff and luck for 4–6 players, from designer Sebastian Bleasdale.

You’re a cyclist competing for position in the peloton, but overtaking the leaders isn’t easy. You’ll need skill in bluffing and a healthy dose of luck. Can you out-think the other riders and reach the head of the pack in time to seize victory?

GeoPicnic
Do you know what is the name of this province? And the name of the capital?
Have fun learning and practicing spanish geography. And win 10 Picnics (points) for each correct answer.

     Includes 52 cards, a plastic sandwich box, and "Picnic" tickets.


GeoPicnic
¿Sabes cuál es esta provincia? ¿Y su capital? ¿Y la comunidad autónoma a la que pertenece?
Diviértete aprendiendo y practicando un poco de geografía de España. Y gana 10 Picnics (puntos) por cada respuesta acertada.

    Incluye 52 cartas, sandwichera de plástico y pack de billetes Picnics.

Plyt is a great new family board game for players of ALL ages and abilities to play together in a fun, competitive and challenging way and, even better, it improves your numeracy skills!

The game is easy to play and works around multiplying a number of 12 sided dice together within the agreed time, negotiating the Plyt squares and racing against each other to be the first to reach the winner square.  But there’s a balance of risk and reward. Plyters decide how many dice to throw to try and get ahead, and when it comes to it, who they will push back or help.  It starts off gently to let you get the feel of it but as the play gets closer to the end, positions can change quickly and the result isn’t certain until the very last throw!

But Plyt isn’t just about beating your opponents – it’s also about challenging yourself – pushing yourself out of your comfort zone and feeling the buzz of getting it right!
There are lots of different playing options you can choose (all described in the rules and on the website) – it all depends how competitive you want the game to be and how long you want it to last.  The basic game normally lasts between 25-45 minutes but you can make this shorter or longer – it’s up to you!

Come Forth and Multiply!

In the light strategy game Body Builders, 3-6 players assume the role of lonely taxidermists who recruit vultures, hyenas, crocodiles and other critters to scavenge for animal parts that can be combined to build themselves a friend. Players recruit these scavengers with dice through a combination of choice and chance, and they use this army of scavengers to invade opposing taxidermists to try to steal the parts they need to complete their new pal and thus win the game.

Game Information:
This game is intended for 2-6 players, ages 7 and up, preferably with an adult. Calculators can be a helpful tool and are allowed to be incorporated for use. A game should take 30-45 minutes from start to finish.
Players take turns playing out their hands of numbers and sign cards to get their totals as close to the randomly selected red target number card.

Object:
The first player to win five or more red target cards is the winner.

Monster Math cards are some of the best learning aids for mathematics, as opposed to flash cards which have a suggested problem preformed on the card. Monster Math allows the tutor to rearrange the numbers and signs so that the student can see how they would interact in real time. By simply moving a number from the bottom of the equation to the top, the student would get to experience and make the connections themselves as to how the math interacts with the numbers and signs, and the tutor can demonstrate the relationship of numbers and signs with proficiency so that the student could repeat the process for themselves.

Romans vs Britons plays out an ambush of a small troop of Roman soldiers marching along a Roman road sometime in the mid first century AD. They are in a valley when they spot fearsome Britons coming down from the surrounding hills.  Orthogonal movement and custodial capture Captains (2 each) can capture more that one enemy. Three different levels of win depending on whether the loser manages to escape, surrender or is entirely defeated.  Leather board and wooden gaming pieces.

Vikings vs Saxons plays out a skirmish between the Saxon settlers of dark age Britain and incoming Vikings some time in the 8th century. They meet at a bridge and fight to the death. There are three categories of men: Swords-men (movement: ortho/diag 3/2 squares); Axe-men (movement: ortho/diag 2/1 squares); Spear-men (movement: knights move). Two levels of winning depending on whether the loser surrenders/escapes or is entirely defeated. Leather board and wooden gaming pieces.

Royalists vs Roundheads represents a battle in the first few years of the Civil Wars of the 17th century.  Royalists and Roundheads line up their Cavaliers, Pikemen and Musketeers and the battle begins.  Three types of men each with different movement: Pikemen (movement: ortho/diag forwards only 1 square, capture by replacement); Musketeers (movement: ortho/diag 3/2, capture by replacement); Cavaliers  (movement: ortho/diag 1 square, capture by long leap). Aim to capture opposing general ( a Cavalier). Leather board and wooden gaming pieces.

Tomb Robbers and Temple Raiders plays out a clash between two groups of treasure hunting robbers and raiders amongst the temple ruins of Egypt in the 1920s. All men on both sides move by the knight's move (x1 or x2) and capture by  alignment. Secret passages allow an extra degree of movement across the board. Two levels of win depending on whether the losing side can allow their last man to escape or is defeated entirely. Leather board and wooden gaming pieces.

"18 giugno 1815: Waterloo" is a hex and counter wargame simulation of the battle of Waterloo, for two opponents and two possible difficulty levels.

The counters represent all the units that actually took part into the battle. A unit is normally at regimental level.

Game length is between 10 and 12 turns. Each turn corresponds to 60 minutes of real time.

Victory is calculated according to points gained for fulfilled objectives minus points lost following the elimination of the gamer's own units.

"La Battaglia del Lago Ghiacciato" (The Iced Lake Battle) is a paper-miniatures wargame based on the battle of Lake Peipus (1242) as inspired by Sergej Ejzenstejn's movie "Alexandr Nevskij".

The map is divided into squares and the units are beautiful stand-up paper soldiers (that the players have to cut and mount) designed by Guido Crepax, representing Russians and Teutonic knights.

Victory is gained when a certain difference between players' points is reached or, alternatively, with the elimination of one of the two armies. Points are assigned according to the quality and the quantity of eliminated enemy units.

Children's educational game about European flags. Players roll two dice with a colour on each face, and must find a tile showing a flag containing the two resulting colours, and then place it on the right space on the map which forms the game board. Each correct match and placement yields a coin; identifying and placing one's own country's flag gives a bonus coin in addition to this. The player who has collected the most coins when all tiles have been placed is the winner.

No upper limit on the number of players is given or implied; at least up to five players seems reasonable.

Mervyn Peake’s extraordinary ‘gothic’ novels, centered on the castle of Gormenghast, have captured the imaginations of millions of readers worldwide, turning the work into a cult classic. The atmosphere of the rambling and decaying castle of Gormenghast with its intrigues, its rituals, its morbid humour and its sheer eccentricity has been a lovingly recreated in this amazing board game.

In this board game each player takes on the role of a ‘kitchen rat’ similar to Steerpike in the books. Like Steerpike you have the same murderous desire for power. Your goal is to accumulate as much influence as you can (in the form of Victory Tokens),
rise to the top and become Master of Ritual. To acquire Victory Tokens players move characters around the board to complete various intrigues (detailed on Plot Cards). When a player completes a plot they gain Victory Tokens. The first player to acquire 9 (or more) Victory Tokens wins the game.

Contents
Rule book
book of ritual
10 x character pieces
30 x castle tiles
Three card decks totaling 106 cards - 66 action cards, 10 character cards and 30 plot cards
30 x artefact tokens
20 x influence tokens
40 x victory tokens
1 x blocking token
1 x ritual die

Get ready for an ultimate Skylanders adventure as you battle Kaos and his minions. Place one of the fighting-action lenticular cards into your mover base and start exploring the 6 different islands. Defeat villains in order to collect keys and charms, but watch out! If Kaos shows up, all active Skylanders lose some of their power.

Contents: 6 island game boards, 32 lenticular Skylanders cards, 34 reward tiles, 34 challenge tiles, 8 starter activation tokens, 4 keys, 4 card holder movers, game die, rules.
In the card game nullern, a throwback to card games of yesteryear, players try to predict the number of tricks they'll take, suffering "Hupfer" — negative points — when incorrect.

The 300 Mile Race Game is a board game which simulates a stock car race with 30 participants.  The object of the game is to pick the winning car from among the 30 cars in the game.  Dice are rolled against a sequence of tables to determine which cars get to advance around the track.  The tables also have results which can cause cars to suffer pit stops, crashes, or mechanical failures.  The first car around the track wins, along with the player who picked that car (if any).

Players strive to become the surrogate of Luxembourg's national comic superhero: Superjhemp. To do so, they must fulfill missions and take control of Luxembourg's cantons by proving their knowledge about Luxembourg's history and present.

In this trivia game, every player draws a secret mission card at the start of the game. This tells the player which cantons (pairs of spaces on the map) have to be controlled by the player in order to win.

Players traverse the map from north to south. Every time they land on one space, a card from that space is drawn and a random trivia question is asked. If the player knows the answer, he can put a marker on the space. If both spaces from one canton are marked, the player controls that canton. It is possible for players to wrest control of a half or full canton away from a player controlling them.

The goal of Mutiny is to stay alive while eliminating your opponents. Keeping your allies safe is also a good idea. But... better them than you right? You’re a pirate after all!

Players are given role cards to determine their allegiance and who they will play as for the game. Players can be divided into 3 groups, Traitors, Loyal shipmates and the captain.

Traitors try to eliminate the captain, who is known by everyone, and the loyal mates while the shipmates try to defend the captain and kill all the traitors. The captain's goal is simply to stay alive, but since he's the only one oblivious to the other players loyalty, it can be harder than it looks.

The two main groups will then decide, one after the other, which meal they want to poison and once this is done the round can start. One after the other, players will switch their meals with one another. Once everyone did their action, everyone will reveal their meal card. Those who have been poisoned are removed from the game and those who survive continue to the next round.

This goes on until every traitors or mates has died or until the Captain dies.

"Vietnam Solitaire Special Edition" is an expanded edition of the original Vietnam Solitaire that contains both the original game (with all new artwork) and a reimplementation by Steve Kling with expanded rules, new scenarios, and new counters. While primarily a solitaire game, the special edition also contains optional two player rules.

In the Special Edition, the player controls US and South Vietnamese forces and must battle the Vietcong and North Vietnamese Army to control as many regions of Vietnam as possible. The game is played by deploying US and South Vietnamese forces, napalm, and air units on a map of Vietnam. The AI (or an optional second player) controls the North Vietnamese forces through movement and attack rules.

Victory is determined by controlling at least three regions of Vietnam for a majority of the game. Unlike in the original game, the eventual victory of the North Vietnamese is not a foregone conclusion.

The Special Edition contains new types of units, a greater variety of of combat points, and two new scenarios - "Tet 1968" and "Fall of South Vietnam".

Against the Odds broke new ground with the 2010 Annual. Four Roads to Moscow included four different, complete games from four top designers, each one taking their own approach to cover Barbarossa. There have been “quad games” before, but never like this.

While many people are thrilled to get all four, we figured a few folks might have a favored designer and only want that game. We aim to please. So, if you want to try just one or two of the “Four Roads,” the option is here.

Hitler Turns East by Ted Raicer is a classic-style, hex-and-counter wargame that uses chit-pull to keep things fluid. Hitler Turns East focuses on the difficulties of armies cooperating with each other, either for political or personal reasons (and Barbarossa saw lots on both sides).

The new printing of Hitler Turns East comes with 144 updated die-cut 9/16" counters, and a 17" x 22" full color map, plus updated rules and charts.

(from the ATO website "Black Swans" section)

In Dystopian: the manhunt, one to four players assume the role of special agents of the Dystopia Police Department (called Sector 9), with the goal of investigating a murder case, finding the criminal, among four suspects and, eventually, catching him, it or her, before he gets away.
The agents will move around the megalopolis of Dystopia, investigating the numerous locations (distributed among districts and suburbs) meeting people, talking to them, gaining and finding hints and leads that make the investigation progress, bringing them closer and closer to the murderer.
Dystopia is a City controlled by two rival Corporations (Varcom and Infracorp), that are in the business of AI-Roids: artificially intelligent robots that live with the humans.
Dystopia features a plethora of many different locations, where the players will have to conduct their investigation.

Dystopian: the manhunt features the following mechanics: worker placement, variable player powers, action selection, network building, cooperative/solitaire play, press your luck.

The players will have to roll dice, and allocate them on their agent's sheet to gain these resources: 
1) warrants: to enter a location
2) attack: to respond to an attack from an encounter
3) evade: to hide from an attack from an encounter
4) interact: to interact with encounters or locations
5) analyze: to analyze hints and gain evidence about who committed the crime

Such resources will be used to deal with encounters the players will meet around the city, to advance their agent's abilities, ultimately, to catch the suspect who is found guilty.

The game is divided in 2 stages: the first is the Search, where players have to discovered who, among the 4 suspects, committed the crime; and the second, the Chase, where the suspect tries to hide in Dystopia, and it's up to the agents to seize him (it or her).

Rush is the primary title.

The entire title would be...

Colorado's Green

Rush

It is (as the name implies) about the 21st century rush currently underway in Colorado, meaning...

The legalization of Marijuana.

It is a game about trying to make money in this crazy industry.

It's like the Wild-Wild-West all over again!!!

Rush is an economic game that involves the fact that law enforcement is always angling to shut down your enterprise.

We here at Common Man Games have always taken a special interest in games that are themed after modern-day subject matters, and involve Law Enforcement.

We think this is a very interesting topic, and one that is evolving right before our eyes.

We began work on this game back in 2013 and hoped to release it in 2014, but getting it right has been a long slow process and one we don't want to "Rush" (sorry), so exactly when it will be released is a tricky question to answer, but please...

Stay Tuned!

Castle Rising is a German-style board game in which you choose an economic strategy to try to create the most prosperous kingdom. Players acquire resources (food, wood, stone, metal and gold) to train troops and construct buildings to earn benefits at different stages of the game and victory points to win the game.

Players can acquire resources in three ways, the main one being through your peasants, with each player starting with three. You decide which resources to produce, but some are easier to get than others, so you can play it safe or risk trying for a few more precious resources. You can also gain resources through rangers, which you must first train, which takes several units of food and wood.

The last way to gain resources is through the bidding phase. Each turn, all players bid secretly on one of five different resource bundles.

A desperate tale of rodents and river crossings, Of Mice and Lemmings sees between five and eight players attempt to cross a thunderous stretch of water in order to reach the safe haven of a brand new cheese factory on the other bank. However, while the mice will be looking to fill their stomachs with all that high-quality dairy product, the lemmings have another idea: Scupper the bridges that are being built and plunge into the torrent below! Combining elements of both teamwork and individual play, you'll be looking to choose the right time to reveal your true nature while screwing over your opposite numbers.

In the game, players add cards to the central pool, numbered from 0 to 10. Depending on how many people are playing, a certain target number must be reached; 35, for example, with eight players. Each round, one player MUST reveal whether she is a mouse or lemming, then rely on her fellow rodents to get them all across the bridge — or not, as the case may be! Reveal too early and you could be putting too much faith in the other players; reveal too late and there's a good chance you may not be successful!

Of Mice and Lemmings is a quirky update on the trick-taking genre and adds hidden identities, a healthy amount of bluffing, and rodents with one-track minds.

From fire to smartphone in less than an hour!

S-Evolution is a unique combination of a classic card game — with tricks, colors and trump — and of a typical "Eurogame" of resources management and civilization. Each player has a deck of 24 cards, and in each of the six rounds, he draws a hand of four cards from this deck. Each player starts the game in Age 1 and adds the progress card of this age to his deck.

Each round consists of a card phase, lasting 4-5 tricks among all the players, followed by an individual management phase. During the card phase, players try to (1) gather resources (which are on the cards) to pay for the needs of their civilization and to construct buildings, (2) avoid diasters, and (3) collect discoveries. However, the value of a player's cards are affected by which Age he occupies. In Ages 1 and 2, for example, his cards have no color, so they automatically lose to cards of players in Age 3 and above as those folks have discovered the awesome power of hue. What's more, in the primitive Age 1, you can't see the cards before you play them. That's how primitive you are! In Ages 5 and 6, a player can start using trump to beat out those in lower ages.

The advantages in the card phase are balanced by the needs of your population, which is much greater in later ages. In each trick, each player collects one played card based on the value of their card played, and players then use the resources on these cards (food, tools and science) to satisfy the needs of their population, erect buildings (which supply additional resources), gain advantages (which can protect you from disasters or earn you victory points), or advance to the next Age of S-Evolution. Players score points each round depending on how well they meet the needs of their population, suffering penalties if they fail to do so.

At the end of the sixth round, players score points for their sets of discoveries, and the player with the highest score wins!

Dice Crawl is a quick, fun dungeon-crawling tile game for 1 to 4 players. Players take on the roles of mercenary captains racing to get their team of adventurers to the center of the dungeon, while other captains try to do the same thing.

Dice Crawl comes with 48 interchangeable tiles, including 4 races, 4 classes, and 4 quick reference tiles. Players will need to provide their own 6-sided dice (roughly 20-25 are needed per player), otherwise you’d be buying a box of dice. And we know you have dice!

Each player works to gain control of the dungeon as they search for the center. The game ends when a player runs out of dice or someone finds the center of the dungeon.

Beware! Not all paths lead to the center and some teams may never find the glory they seek. Luck and strategy combine in this furious game of hack-and-slashery!

Every answer is correct – with one exception from which you'd better keep your "Finger weg", that is to say, hands off. Otherwise, the high tension will overload and the fuse will blow!

Each round in Finger weg!, one of 287 cards in seven categories is placed into a special device — the "fuse box". This card shows one task or challenge and eight answers, one of them being false; the fuse box hides this information behind small sliding gates for each answer.

On a turn, the active player announces which one of the answers not yet chosen is correct. All of the other players now either join him in this opinion or quit the round. The player then moves the slider, and if he was correct, all players who haven't yet quit benefit — but maybe he was wrong...

Players who quit the round cannot rejoin for later answers, giving up any additional profit for each subsequent correct answer, so the main challenge of the game is to quit at the right time.

Finger weg! includes a 48-page booklet of facts and background about the tasks.

The innkeeper of "The Wild Boar" tavern is a sly old dog! While they treat humble guests who don't ask for much to free rounds, for hard-drinking boozers they close the tap and keep the cool brew for themself.

Polterfass is a dice-rolling game without dice! Yes, the dice have been replaced by small beer barrels, and the active player each round is the innkeeper who shares their brew with players who keep their requests modest.

The game includes nine barrels — two of them being special ones — that are rolled out of a dice cup. The normal barrel bases show numbers, while the special barrel bases show symbols that allow the innkeeper to double other values or cancel them. After each roll, only the values/symbols of "standing" barrels count.

After the active player has rolled for the first time, the other players secretly place cards with numbers in front of them. The active player then decides whether to reroll, change the values, or end their turn. Once their turn ends, the guests reveal their cards and sum them. If the innkeeper's total is less than this sum, they win this round, keeping all the beer for themself while the guest with the highest card actually loses points! If the innkeeper's total is higher, each player scores the value of their played card, and the innkeeper keeps the rest.

When one player has at least 75 points, the game ends, and the player with the most points wins!

The breakfast worms are coming! Twelve hungry baby birds stretch their wide-open beaks into the air. Will the busy parent birds manage to get enough food for all of them?

In Schmatzspatz, four wooden birds sit on the edges of the circular rotating "board in the box", each with a worm in its beak. In the middle area are twelve hungry little birds with open mouths. A symbol die determines the sector of the board where the most hungry baby birds are. The player now decides which one of these birds to feed and tries to rotate the board to move one of the adult birds to the right position.

The turning board occasionally blocks the feeding, however,so the players must remember these "blocked" positions. When the worm can successfully be fed to the bird, the baby closes its beak. If the players manage to feed all the baby birds before running out of worms, they win the game together.

Schmatzspatz includes a competitive version in which each player tries to get rid of his worm supply first.

Do you have what it takes to be a knight of the round table?

King Arthur has an opening in his legendary roster of heroes! With just the right combination of strength, fortitude, and originality, the job is yours!
Accept His Majesty's quests, make the realm a better place, and secure your name in the history books... before your rivals get a chance!

Each turn players roll dice and commit them to match different quests from the king. Collect sets of matching colored quests or one of each to win the game.

GenDu "The Gentleman's Duel" is a trading card game where you play as a gentleman in The world of the Gents. You can challenge other gentleman to a duel to test their might and prove your own. The gentlemen set up dungeons and battle to the death.In the game players build their respective dungeons while the objective is to get one of their nouns (also referred to as creatures) through the opposing player's dungeon whilst destroying anything in its path. Both players build dungeons and then try to conquer each other, which makes for an intense experience.

Gentlemen duel for many reasons; honor, respect, recognition, fancy shoes, the love of a fair maiden, crisp bacon, a good shawarma, or to maybe one day be a
Master Gentleman.


    Gentlemen can build their own deck of 50 cards and duel against other Gentleman.
    You can also purchase Starter Decks, which are a built deck of 50 cards ready to play. All Starter Decks are random.
    Or you can purchase Booster Packs and build your own deck from scratch.
    Trade with your friends to get cards that will help your deck and increase your odds of winning
    Or try and collect all 136 different cards in the series.


The cards in a Gentleman's deck are the powers and defense they have at their disposal to defeat any challenger. Build wisely.

For more information on how to play GenDu The Gentleman's Duel. Check out our Game Play Video on our Rules page.

You can also create your own GenDu cards!!!

GenDu The Gentleman's Duel is the first and only trading card game ( TCG ) where all cards released in every series are created by the players.


    Every Booster pack and Starter deck comes with blank GenDu cards.
    Starter decks have 3 blank cards and Booster packs have 1. 
    Players draw their card ideas on the cards provided and Send Them In.
    Players can also use our Card Maker online to submit cards.
    The cards are  posted on our Facebook page for votes.
    The cards with the highest votes are printed into the next series.
    Author of the card has their name printed on the card
    Author also gets first copy of the printed card sent to them for FREE!


This is what sets GenDu apart from any other TCG. Now for the first time players have an opportunity to be a part of the game creation. Furthermore with player input and collaboration, GenDu can will always remain fresh and interesting. We welcome all players to send in as many ideas as they want so that they have a better chance of one of them being picked to be in the next release of GenDu.

The Gentleman's Duel awaits....

The player is the CEO of a movie studio during the golden age of Hollywood (1927-1955). Competition for talented people is fierce, and the public's tastes in movies change all the time. The player has to manage and hire new people, and approve the right films, so that the have as much Fame (victory points) as possible, at the end of the game.

Created for the 2013 Solitaire Print and Play contest, Cine-vilzation uses six small containers to manage the production and payout of film genres.  Players have to do their best to predict when films will become popular, as timing a film release correctly will earn the player fame and clout in the film industry, which can help produce even more films.

Twelve film types are grouped into three genres centered around the resources that make Hollywood run, capital, acclaim and power.  Players keep track of these resources, using tokens, dice and cards. The tokens can only be used once, and may need to be held to pay upkeep costs at the end of each round.  Cards can be played to help pay for a film, but holding on to them will generate tokens. Dice can be used multiple times, but cost tokens each round.  Dice also control an invisible opponent, who tries to get cards before you do, and speeds up the end of the game.

Players will have to evaluate their supply of resources, the popularity of films, and how much time remains to try to make the best films they can.   When resources are dedicated to a film, they get placed into a container, and will be unavailable for several rounds.  The containers shift during upkeep, with any dice inside the first container getting rolled for the AI.

Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers vs. X-Men is a collectible dice-building tabletop game designed by Quarriors! creators Michael Elliott and Eric M. Lang.

In this game, each player fields one of the superhero teams, with each hero — Captain America, Wolverine, Spider-Man, and more — being represented by custom-tooled dice; each team must be composed of up to 20 dice, and a player can "purchase" dice only from his team. Each hero also has one or more character reference cards, which show the special abilities for the characters based on the die rolls. Different versions of these cards will be available in booster packs, allowing for more customization of your team. Players use these dice to collect energy, recruit new heroes, and battle head-to-head. In addition, each player brings two basic action cards to the game, which are placed in the center of the table; both players can purchase these cards. A player wins once the opposing player has been reduced to zero life.

The Marvel Dice Masters: Avengers vs. X-Men starter set comes with 44 custom dice, 38 cards, two dice bags, and a core rulebook. Booster packs include two dice with two matching character cards.

A game set in the Battlestar Galactica Universe using a variation of Dice of Arkham by Mads L. Brynnum.

The Setting: After the Cylon surprise attack that wiped out the 12 colonies of man, the Battlestar Galactica leads a rag-tag fleet of the last remaining humans on a long and perilous journey to Kobol, the home of the lost 13th Tribe. You control the fleet as you make you way to your new home, deciding when to run, when to fight, and how to survive.

Game Overview: This game is more than a simple re-skinning of "Dice Of Arkham", the mechanic has been changed and modified to lend itself to this unique Sci-Fi Universe, yet it remains true to its heritage. Those familiar with "Dice Of Arkham" will have no problem picking this game up. For those who aren't, first of all I recommend you grab DoA RIGHT NOW (the link to it is above). It's an excellent game! There is also a very complete set of rules that will explain this game fully included in the pdf.

Components:
Game Sheet & Rules (which you print)
8 tokens (which you provide)
8 Dice, 6 of one color and 2 of a second color (which you also provide)

Approximate Game Length: 10-20 minutes

Gameplay: Each turn you roll your Jump Prep Dice (6 dice, however you only roll 5 of them until you complete the first "Humans" event) to perform your actions such as repairing your ships or advancing along the Jump Preparation Track. You will also roll the Draidis Dice (2 dice) once per turn which shows you what Cylon threats will have to be resolved in this area of space before you can continue. The Cylons are also attempting to move down their track and perform Traitorous Acts to prevent the Humans from reaching the home of the lost 13th Tribe, Kobol. As each side completes their Track, an event is triggered. If the Cylons complete 3 events before the humans do, you lose. If you complete 3 before the cylons do, you win!

This game will ALWAYS be free to Print and Play!

--Lord Malachi

Submitted for the 2013 Solitaire Print and Play Contest

Juego de simulación de un partido de baloncesto.
El juego traía un tablero que representaba una cancha de baloncesto.
Cada jugador dirigía dos equipos, y tenían que jugar todo el partido, resolviéndose todas las situaciones con tiradas de dados.

Simulation game of a basketball game. The game has a board depicting a basketball court. Each player runs two teams, and they have to play the entire game, solving all situations with dice rolls.

Dribling is a basketball simulation game which is situated halfway between classic board games, strategy or letters. Each participating player takes the role of coach and can design a complete basketball team and fully tailored from the creation of the various players. Source: Publisher's website

Who will be the best trader in Chicago Stock Exchange? Players trade in goods, seeking to keep the best-valued goods for themselves while ruining the values of those held by other players.

To start the game, shuffle the 36 tokens — which depict six types of goods — then place them in nine stacks, with the stacks in a circle. On a turn, the active player moves a pawn 1-3 stacks, then takes the top token from the two stacks adjacent to this pawn. He keeps one token for his own holdings and sells the other, lowering the value of that good by one. (Wheat starts with a value of 7, and the other goods start at 6.) When only two stacks remain, the game ends and players tally the value of their holdings to see who best judged (and manipulated) the market.

In the expert version of the game, the active player can move any number of spaces clockwise around the stacks, but must stop if he reaches a stack topped with the same type of good as that of the stack from which he started his movement.

Hiding in these woods, there lies not just one Bigfoot, not a few Bigfoots, and not a gaggle of Bigfeet — but an entire community of Bigfootses. Now it's time to go in the woods with your trusty Bigfootses's call, cloak your scent with Bigfootses's urine, and get ready for adventure with aliens, yeti, the Loch Ness monster, and every other legendary creature you can think of.

Bigfootses, The Card Game consists of two decks: the Woods Deck (75 cards) and the Thingies Deck (75 cards). In the Woods Deck, you encounter Bigfootses and creatures to battle, and draw events that can dramatically change the game. The Thingies Deck is full of equipment, items, actions, and card modifiers to help you along in your quest.  Also included are 10 professions, ranging from the practical to the absurd.

Your goal? Be the first player to corral ten Bigfootses to win the game!

Not enough gas, not enough ammo or not enough time. Not enough to cross the Rhine before the enemy closes all the gaps. You need to form the bridgehead before others do. That’s the only way to Victory and your personal glory.

1944 Race to the Rhine is a new game experience. You can’t win this game without proper planning. Your tanks need gas to move and ammo to fight. But don’t forget to feed your GIs. So what would be your transport priority?

Will you follow General Patton’s strategy to discard ammo in order to bring additional fuel barrels along to move boldly forward? Would you risk your prestige and gamble on Market-Garden as Field Marshal Montgomery did? Would you cross the Rhine more quickly than General Bradley did, with the help of your hard work and a little luck?

“In preparing for battle I have always found that plans are useless, but planning is indispensable” (General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces in Europe).

So, how are you planning your Victory?

September 1, 1939 – For the second time in the 20th century, the world is at war. With the invasion of Poland by Germany, Europe plunges into war a mere 20 years after the end of The Great War, now to be known as World War I. Just over two years later, in December of 1941, the other half of the globe joins the war as Japan declares war on the United States and the British Commonwealth and tears through Western Pacific territories with astonishing ease. Will you save the free world as the Allies, or conquer it as the Axis?

WWII: The Card Game is a 2 player card game that pits the Axis against the Allied Powers in the Second World War. WWII: The Card Game is a constructed deck game in which both players construct their own deck before the game begins and then use their deck to wage war on their opponent. During the game, players build their resources and deploy military units to take control of locations by defeating their opponent’s units in battle. By winning battles and controlling key strategic locations around the world, players cause their opponent to lose cards from their deck. The first player to empty their opponent’s deck is the winner!

In Circus Divas, a two-player dice-buying game, you play the owner of a Depression-era circus going from town to town parting fools and their money. But in order to do that, you need to hire some help and, ultimately, earn more than the rival circus that keeps hitting the same towns you do and draining your profits.

Each player can hire performers for his or her circus from a common pool. Those performers each allow the player to roll one additional die for profit, from the lowly d4 to the mighty - but unpredictable - d20. But these performers can prove to be real divas. When a performer rolls a 1, he or she throws a diva's tantrum and has to be consoled - or he or she will quit. And if you're consoling one diva, you can't console another if they should have a tantrum, so choose carefully.

The first player to reach $100 in savings wins. Play time takes about 15 minutes and requires at least one d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, and d20 to play. Counters for money are also helpful, but pencil and paper could work just fine. Enjoy it, and please let me know what you think!

Draw Blood is a rummy-style card game for 2-3 players, with a deck that consists of 54 cards: three types of monsters (Vampires, Werewolves and Water Monsters), three "Kill" cards (for killing your opponent's Monsters), and 36 numbered blood cards.

Like most rummy games, the object of Draw Blood is to be the first player to get rid of all the cards in your hand. To do this, players can lay down melds of sets and runs; unlike other rummy games, however, you can't just lay down melds whenever you want. You must play a monster card first. Knowing when to play monsters is a key strategy, but you also have to figure out when to kill your opponent's monsters to prevent them from laying down their own melds.

The numbered blood cards come in two colors: odd numbers are black and have a skull in the right corner, while even numbers are red and have a heart in the right corner. You can kill your opponent's monsters with a Kill card or a three-of-a-kind of skulls. With a three-of-a-kind of hearts, you can bring one of your monsters back to life. Blood cards can also be played as melds for points, and deciding whether to play for points or to kill your opponents becomes a key strategy in the game.

The first player to play out his cards ends the hand, then everyone tallies his score. Whoever first reaches a preset point total wins!

YÅkaï no Mori contains two simpler versions of Shogi to introduce the game to new players and youngsters.

In the classic version, each player has only four pieces – kodama, tanuki, kitsune, and koropokkuru – and they're trying to either catch the opponent's koropokkuru or move their own koropokkuru to the opposite side of the game board. The board is just 3×4 squares, so the game is rather short. As for how to play:


     The tanuki moves one space orthogonally.
     The kitsune moves one space diagonally.
     The kodama is directly analogous to the pawn/soldier of ShÅgi and can be promoted to a kodama samurai, equivalent to the gold general in Shogi (moving one space orthogonally or one space diagonally forward).
     The koropokkuru is analogous to a king in Chess, except that he can win through promotion as long as it doesn't leave him in check.
     Even on this 3×4 board, you are still able to drop in pieces that you captured from your opponent!
     Unlike in ShÅgi, you can drop a kodama for mate or have two kodama in a column.


The expert version has a larger 5×6 game board with each player having eight pieces (3 kodama, 2 oni, 2 kirin and 1 koropokkuru).


     The kirin moves equivalent to the gold general in Shogi.
     The oni moves equivalent to the silver general in Shogi (moving one space diagonally or one space straight forward) and can be promoted to a super oni, equivalent to the gold general in Shogi.


The game also adds more rules from the full ShÅgi game, in particular:


     You win only by capturing your opponent's koropokkuru, not by reaching the opposite side of the game board.
     You can't have two of your own kodama in the same column/file.
     You can't drop a kodama for mate.


The Japan Shogi Association created the rules for this game in order for players to learn important concepts in ShÅgi, such as how to handle the generals effectively, why pawn promotion is so important, and how to mate the opponent's king with successive piece drops.
